data.title: THE SPANISH MARRIAGE KING ALFONSO AND PRINCESS ENA.
data.meta_description: King Alfonso XIII, of Spain was married yesterday in the Church of San Geronimo to Princess Ena of Battenberg, and unhappily on this day, the anniversary of the anarchist attempt on the life of King Alfonso at Paris, the wedding was marred by another bomb outrage, ...
data.text:
DISASTROUS EXPLOSION OF A BOMB.

Returning from the Church of San Geronimo, the procession

halted temporarily on the Calle mayor Bouquets, which were

showered from the balconies on the Royal couple, included one

which concealed a steel bomb. The missile exploded towards the

right, between the hindermost horses and the front wheel of the

Royal carriage. The groom was killed with two horses; the carriage

was damaged.

The Marquis of Sottomayor, Grand Chamberlain, and an equerry,

who were riding on the right, were wounded. A lieutenant standing

at the salute and four soldiers lining the route were killed. The

explosion decapitated a police bugler, besides killing two women

spectators and injuring numbers of other spectators.

KING ALFONSO'S GALLANTRY.

The Duke of Cornaohuelos, rushing forward, opened the door of

the Royal carriage, and dragged out King Alfonso and then Queen

Ena, who exhibited great emotion. Both reached the palace uninjured.

At the moment of the explosion, recovering himself immediately,

King Alfonso spoke through the broken windows of the carriage, and

inquired what damage had been done. Forthwith he sent an orderly

to reassure the Princess Beatrice, the mother of his bride, and the

Queen Mather, Christina-Maria, and raising his voice he ordered

the procession to proceed.

Queen Ena, who was deathly pale, smiled courageously, and

soon King Alfonso and his bride were helped out, and continued the

journey in another coach. The Queen broke down on reaching the

palace. Courtiers pressed forward, but King Alfonso waved them

back and tenderly supported his weeping wife.

THE PRINCE AND PRINCESS OF WALES.

At the time of the explosion the carriage of the Prince and

Princess of Wales was some distance ahead of that of King Alfonso.

MESSAGES OF SYMPATHY.

The dominant note of comment in the newspapers is one of gratitude.

The providential escape of their majesties is interpreted as of

good augury for the sovereigns' happiness and that of Spain.

Messages of sympathy and congratulations have been received

in the Palace at Spain from all countries- *

The populace was furious at the attempt made on the lives of

the King and his Queen, and they nearly lynched several foreigners,

including a French detective who was suspected during the confusion

of the authorship of the outrage.

SOCIETY MUST PROTECT ITSELF. '.

AUthe newspapers agree that it is high time for society to take

energetic measures to protect itself from the danger of high explosives

falling into the hands of anarchists and homicides, The newspapers

also urge a reconsideration of the laws and attitude of the

people towards secret societies,

v Strangely enough, a bomb emanated from the only house owned

by the Queen Mother in Madrid. It was the bequest of a philanthropist,

and is let as a grocery on the ground floor, and a boarding

establishment above.

It is supposed that the bomb thrower is one Manuel Duran, a

well-dressed Catalonian. He and many others have been arrested.

THE DEATH ROLL.

The Madrid correspondent of the " Daily Telegraph" states that

three officers, seven soldiers, and five spectators were killed by the

explosion of the bomb, and that 100 were injured more or less

seriously, some of the injured being on the first floor balcony of the

house from which the bomb was thrown.
